'''Mary Cynthia Walsh''' {{postnom|CM}} <ref>{{cite web|url=http://isn.net/iode/awards.html|title=Six individuals received a University of Prince Edward Island Doctor of Laws Degrees, honoris causa in May 2003.|publisher=Lake of Shining Awards|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081121035540/http://www.isn.net/iode/awards.html|archivedate=2008-11-21|df=}}</ref> (born May 13, 1952) is a Canadian [[actress]], [[comedian]] and [[social activist]].<ref name=canenc>[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/mary-walsh/ "Mary Walsh"]. ''[[The Canadian Encyclopedia]]'', January 1, 2012.</ref>
== Early life == Walsh was born in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]], the daughter of Mary and Leo Walsh, a merchant marine turned firefighter on commercial vessels. She's the 7th of 8 children. She is also of Irish ancestry.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/whodoyouthinkyouare/stories/ext_mary.php |title=Who Do You Think You Are? |work=Cbc.ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331114451/http://www.cbc.ca/whodoyouthinkyouare/stories/ext_mary.php |archivedate=March 31, 2009 }}</ref>
==Career== Walsh studied [[theatre]] in [[Toronto]] at [[Ryerson University]] but dropped out to work with the [[CODCO]] comedy troupe on a series of stage shows, which eventually evolved into a sketch comedy series.<ref name=early>{{cite web|title=Mary Walsh: Warrior princess - Everything Zoomer - Boomers with Zip|url=http://www.everythingzoomer.com/mary-walsh-warrior-princess/|website=Everything Zoomer - Boomers with Zip|accessdate=17 October 2016|date=1 January 2006}}</ref> The ''CODCO'' series ran from 1987 to 1992 on [[CBC Television]].
===This Hour Has 22 Minutes=== In 1992, she began to work with former co-star [[Rick Mercer]] and former ''CODCO'' co-stars [[Cathy Jones]] and [[Greg Thomey]] to create a new television series called ''[[This Hour Has 22 Minutes]]''.<ref name=early /> The show would be a parody of the nightly news and would poke fun at Canadian and international politics. ''22 Minutes'' received strong ratings during its earlier seasons and Walsh's character Marg Delahunty became famous for buttonholing politicians and submitting them to satirical interviews.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mary Walsh resurrects Marg to bring change to Ottawa|url=https://ca.news.yahoo.com/blogs/canada-politics/mary-walsh-resurrects-marg-to-bring-change-to-134904937.html|website=ca.news.yahoo.com|accessdate=17 October 2016}}</ref> Usually Marg Delahunty would recite a scripted piece intended to humiliate the politician, often by providing criticism and "grandmotherly" advice. Sometimes Marg appeared as "Marg, Princess Warrior", a parody of the title character of ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]'' portrayed by [[Lucy Lawless]]. Walsh is also noted for her comical segment chronicling the [[Canadian Auto Workers| Canadian Auto Workers Union]]'s tense blockade of the [[Volvo Halifax Assembly]] plant in 1998. In 2007 she revived Marg Delahunty for the [[Royal Canadian Air Farce]]'s 300th episode, filmed in Toronto in March. On October 24, 2011, Walsh was once again in the spotlight as she reprised the role of Marg Delahunty conducting an ambush interview of Toronto Mayor [[Rob Ford]] at his home. Ford's reaction and alleged verbal abuse directed at 911 operator made national headlines.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/1076717--ford-admits-using-f-word-denies-insulting-911-operator?bn=1|title=Ford admits using f-word, denies insulting a 911 operator |work=Toronto Star | date=October 27, 2011|first1=Brendan|last1=Kennedy|first2=David|last2=Rider}}</ref>
Walsh's other television work included the short-run [[sitcom]]s ''[[Dooley Gardens]]'' in 1999, ''[[Hatching, Matching and Dispatching]]''<ref name=early /><ref>{{cite web|title=HATCHING, MATCHING & DISPATCHING PREMIERES JAN. 6 ON CBC|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/hatching-matching-dispatching-premieres-jan-6-on-cbc-571675.htm|website=marketwired.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> and she had a guest starring role as Miranda Cahill on the CBC television series, ''[[Republic of Doyle]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jake Doyle's last ride: Social media reacts|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/jake-doyle-s-last-ride-social-media-reacts-to-republic-of-doyle-finale-1.2869261|website=CBC News|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> She created the CBC program ''[[Mary Walsh: Open Book]]'', a talk show about books and literature, in 2003.<ref name=early />
Besides TV acting, she has worked on movies such as ''[[Mambo Italiano (film)|Mambo Italiano]]'',<ref name=early /> ''[[Geraldine's Fortune]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Geraldine's Fortune *|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/geraldines-fortune/article1142921/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> ''Rain, Drizzle and Fog'',<ref>{{cite web|title=CM Magazine: Rain, Drizzle and Fog: An Offbeat Look at St. John's, Newfoundland.|url=https://www.umanitoba.ca/cm/vol6/no8/raindrizzlefog.html|website=www.umanitoba.ca|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> ''[[Buried on Sunday]]'', ''[[The Divine Ryans]]'', ''[[Young Triffie]]'' and ''Violet''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hollywood Down East, but you'd never know it|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/hollywood-down-east-but-youd-never-know-it/article1340918/|website=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
===Directing=== Walsh made her feature directorial debut with the 2007 movie ''[[Young Triffie]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=YOUNG TRIFFIE'S BEEN MADE AWAY WITH - Telefilm Canada|url=https://www.telefilm.ca/en/catalogues/production/young-triffie-s-been-made-away|website=www.telefilm.ca|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> She was the first Newfoundlander in six years to have a film in general release across Canada.
===Other work=== 2004 saw Walsh host a segment on the CBC documentary series ''[[The Greatest Canadian]]'', in which she championed the case for Sir [[Frederick Banting]] (the [[Nobel Prize|Nobel]] prize-winning discoverer of [[insulin]]) as the greatest Canadian who ever lived.<ref name=early />
In June 2007, she hosted the [[Pride Week (Toronto)|Pride Toronto]] Gala & Awards ceremony.
On December 15, 2007, Walsh made national news with a story about her upcoming special, ''Nudity, Sexuality, Violence and Coarse Language'', in which a large group of people who went and stripped [[Nudity|naked]] standing next to St. John's [[Harbor|Harbour]] in -11° [[Celsius]] (12.2° [[Fahrenheit]]) temperature to be filmed as a part of the show's closing. Walsh herself did not go nude.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2007/12/15/walsh-nudity-shoot.html |title=Nude St. John's waterfront TV shoot attracts 50 |work=CBC News |date=December 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071216235923/http://www.cbc.ca/arts/tv/story/2007/12/15/walsh-nudity-shoot.html |archivedate=December 16, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2017, Walsh published her debut novel, ''Crying for the Moon''.<ref>[http://vancouversun.com/entertainment/books/mary-walsh-adds-new-novel-to-creative-resume "Mary Walsh adds new novel to creative resume"]. ''[[Vancouver Sun]]'', May 3, 2017.</ref>
==Personal life== Walsh has battled [[alcoholism]].<ref>[https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/two-bell-let-s-talk-ambassadors-share-personal-struggles-with-addiction-1.2753935 ]</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/player/play/2487438195 ]</ref> ''The Toronto Star'' reported that the end of [[CODCO]] coincided with the end of Walsh's active alcoholism, with Walsh stating “which was a damn good thing because I could have never done This Hour Has 22 Minutes if I'd been drinking.”<ref>[https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/2012/03/03/mary_walsh_what_led_marg_delahunty_warrior_princess_to_toronto_mayor_rob_ford.html ]</ref>
== Honours ==
===Performing arts=== She won Best Supporting Actress at the Atlantic Film Festival in 1992 for her performance in Mike Jones' ''[[Secret Nation]]''.<ref name=canenc/>
On November 4, 2006, Walsh and Ed MacDonald picked up a [[Gemini Award]] for the best writing in a comedy or variety program for their work in Hatching, Matching and Dispatching.<ref>{{cite web|title=2006 Gemini Award winners|url=https://www.sootoday.com/local-entertainment/2006-gemini-award-winners-147836|website=SooToday.com|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
She has won 18 [[Gemini Awards]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://academy.ca/hist/history.cfm?nname=Mary+Walsh&winonly=1&awards=0&rtype=1&curstep=4&submit.x=39&submit.y=5|title=Canada's Awards Database}}</ref>
Walsh received a [[Governor General's Performing Arts Award]] for Lifetime Artistic Achievement, Canada's highest honour in the performing arts, in 2012.<ref name="GG">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2012/03/06/gg-performing-arts-awards.html |title=Rush wins Governor General's Award |publisher=CBC News |date=2012-03-06 |accessdate=2012-03-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306221359/http://www.cbc.ca/news/arts/story/2012/03/06/gg-performing-arts-awards.html |archivedate=March 6, 2012 }}</ref>
===Charity and activism=== A sufferer of [[macular degeneration]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Warrior Princess Leads The Charge Against Macular Degeneration {{!}} Optical Prism Magazine|url=http://opticalprism.ca/warrior-princess-leads-the-charge-against-macular-degeneration/|website=opticalprism.ca|accessdate=17 October 2016}}</ref> she has served from time to time as a spokesperson for the [[CNIB|Canadian National Institute for the Blind]] (CNIB).
In 1993, Walsh was chosen to deliver the prestigious [[Graham Spry]] lecture which was broadcast nationally on [[CBC Radio]].<ref name=canenc/>
In 1994, Walsh addressed the [[United Nations]] Global Conference on Development in New York. She has also served as a spokesperson for [[Oxfam]], Canada's human rights campaign, and in 2010 received [[Oxfam]]'s Spirit of Change Award, in recognition of her years of dedication to eradicating poverty and ensuring public services for all.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mary Walsh receives first "Spirit of Change" award|url=http://www.oxfam.ca/news/mary-walsh-receives-first-spirit-change-award|website=Oxfam Canada|accessdate=17 October 2016|date=21 June 2010}}</ref>
On May 29, 1998, Mary Walsh received an Honorary Doctor of Laws from [[Trent University]] <ref>[https://www.trentu.ca/news/fortnightly/feb0598/honorary.html Trentu.ca]</ref>
[[McGill University]] honoured Walsh with an honorary doctorate during the November 2008 convocation ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mcgill.ca/newsroom/news/item/?item_id=102189|title=Mary Walsh and Sheila Fraser to receive honorary degrees at McGill}}</ref> Her speech to the class of 2008 focused on political satire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.journalpioneer.com/index.cfm?sid=190327&sc=121|title=Mary Walsh gets degree from McGill and says PM is a control freak}}</ref>
